questions.question_text: What is the maximum supported RAM per virtual machine (VM) in vSphere 6.5?

discussion.content:
B, C, D is correct.
Procedure:
Browse to a data center in the vSphere Web Client navigator.
Right-click the data center and select New Cluster.
Enter a name for the cluster.
Select DRS and vSphere HA cluster features.
Select an Enhanced vMotion Compatibility (EVC) setting.
Select the vSAN Turn ON check box.
Click OK.
Source: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.5/com.vmware.vsphere.resmgmt.doc/GUID-487C09CE-8BE2-4B89-BA30-0E4F7E3C66F7.html

questions.question_text: Which three features can be configured during the initial creation of a cluster? (Choose three.)

choices.B: The ESXi host is still running but has disconnected from the network.
choices.D: The previous virtual machine cloning operations failed to complete.
choices.C: The ESXi host failed and vSphere HA successfully failed over the virtual machines.
choices.A: The virtual machines were vMotioned off of the ESXi host.

questions.question_text:
A vSphere Administrator sees the alarm:
vSphere HA virtual machine failed to failover
This occurred for a number of virtual machines on a particular ESXi host in a cluster with vSphere High Availability (HA) enabled. The virtual machines guest operating systems never reported a power event.
What happened?

discussion.content: B would be the right answer as guest OS's have not reported a power cycle. ESXi host is disconnected from the Master but still running and has locks on the VM files. Master Node decides to fail over but fails as locks cannot be acquired.
I believe B is the correct answer as C does not make sense to me. It says the vSphere HA failed to failover some Vms and no power action is recorded for VM.
I think B is correct as well
with no power event (restart,shutdown,start) in the VM i think is B : https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2034571

questions.question_text: What two scenarios will prevent extending a VMDK that is attached to a powered on VM? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: That statement is correct, but only for ESX 3.5 and later.

Correct Answer A & C Increasing the size of an IDE virtual disk using the vSphere Client is not supported. SCSI virtual disks are the only supported disk that can be expanded via the vSphere Client.
Reference: https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/1004047

choices.C: VMDK is connected using IDE controller.
choices.B: VMDK is connected using LSI logic SAS controller.
choices.D: VMDK is running an unsupported Guest OS.

questions.question_text: What are the correct steps to migrate the storage of a virtual machine?

discussion.content: Migrating the storage of a VM doesn't involve "Select the destination network for all VM network adapters". Also, you first have to select the datastore before it lets you choose the format. This question needs fixed.

A. Right-click the virtual machine and select Migrate.
Select change storage only.
Select the format for the virtual machine's disks.
Select the datastore to migrate to.
Select the destination network for all VM network adapters Click Finish.

A. Right-click the virtual machine and select Migrate. 
Select change storage only. 
Select the format for the virtual machine's disks. 
Select the datastore to migrate to. 
Select the destination network for all VM network adapters Click Finish. 

B. Right-click the virtual machine and select Migrate. 
Select change compute resource only. 
Select the destination host. 
Select the destination network for all VM network adapters Click Finish. 

C. Right-click the virtual machine and select Migrate. 
Select change both compute resources and storage. 
Select the destination host. Select the format for the virtual machine's disks. 
Select the datastore to migrate to. 
Select the destination network for all VM network adapters Click Finish.
 
D. Right-click the virtual machine and select Migrate. 
Select Migrate virtual machine to a specific datacenter Select the destination datacenter. 
Select the format for the virtual machine's disks. Select the datastore to migrate to. 
Select the destination network for all VM network adapters Click Finish.
Ok it's A? But the image?
